page.title: 18Clapham Park Wood,Bedford
page.content: The wood covers about 29 acres (11.7hectares).It has been there since the Middle Ages.Some of the trees grown are:oak,sycamore,elm,horse chestnut,hazel,maple,ash and fir.The hazel is used for thatching and hedging but the others are used for firewood,pulp and for making fences and gates.The wood belongs and is managed by the Bedfordshire County Council and is divided into five compartments:1-oak,ash,willow and an undergrowth of hazel with dogwood and brambles.2-ash coppice(15 to 20m tall) Scotts Pine is also grown.3-ash coppice.Elm was also grown but most of them are dead or dying.4-oak,ash and hornbeam.Many open areas have been created by the death of sycamore.5-an experimental section with a variety of conifer saplings which are protected by rabbit fence,guards or tree shelter
